de.susebox.jtopas
Interface SequenceHandler

All Superinterfaces:
Plugin
All Known Implementing Classes:
TestPluginTokenizer
Deprecated. replaced by the new SequenceHandler interface

public interface SequenceHandler
extends Plugin

This interface must be implemented by classes that should be used as a special sequence and comment start sequence handler plugin in the PluginTokenizer.

This interface is deprecated. Use the new SequenceHandler interface instead.

Author:
Heiko Blau
See Also:
Tokenizer, AbstractTokenizer

Method Detail

isSequenceCommentOrString

public TokenizerProperty isSequenceCommentOrString(int startingAtPos,
                                                   int maxChars)
                                            throws TokenizerException
Deprecated. 
Return a TokenizerProperty if the character starting at the given position comprise a special sequence (like the ++ operator in C and Java or the &bsp; in HTML), a comment starting sequence or a string sign.
Return null if no special sequence is present at the given position.
Use the AbstractTokenizer.getCharUnchecked(int) to retrieve a character from the tokenizers input buffer.

Parameters:
startingAtPos - check from this position in the tokenizers input buffer
maxChars - analyze at most that number of characters
Returns:
a TokenizerProperty instance describing the special sequence, comment etc. or null if no such thing was found.
Throws:
{@link - de.susebox.java.util.TokenizerException} for any problems
TokenizerException

getSequenceMaxLength

public int getSequenceMaxLength()
Deprecated. 
This method is called by the parent PluginTokenizer to learn how many characters are needed by an instance of this interface to identify a special sequence in the worst case. Usually that should be the length of the longest possible special sequence, comment prefix etc. The tokenizer will make sure that at least this number of characters is available when isSequenceCommentOrString(int, int) is called. If less characters are provided, EOF is reached.

Returns:
the number of characters needed in the worst case to identify a special sequence
